Exercise 1.5.7

Prove Theorem 1.5.10. (Hint: for part (iii), you may wish to use (ii), and first prove that every singleton set is compact.)

Theorem (1.5.10)

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space.

  1. If YYY is a compact subset of XXX, and Z⊆YZ \subseteq YZ⊆Y, then ZZZ is compact if and only if ZZZ is closed.

  3. Every finite subset of XXX (including the empty set) is compact.
Solution.

Then (zn)n⊆Y\p{z_n}_n \subseteq Y(zn​)n​⊆Y, so because YYY is compact, there exists a subsequence (znk)k\p{z_{n_k}}_k(znk​​)k​ which converges to some y0∈Yy_0 \in Yy0​∈Y. But (znk)k⊆Z\p{z_{n_k}}_k \subseteq Z(znk​​)k​⊆Z and znk→y0z_{n_k} \to y_0znk​​→y0​, so because ZZZ is closed, we have y0∈Zy_0 \in Zy0​∈Z. Thus, ZZZ is compact.

  2. Let {Uα}α∈I\set{U_\alpha}_{\alpha \in I}{Uα​}α∈I​ be an open cover of Y1∪⋯∪YnY_1 \cup \cdots \cup Y_nY1​∪⋯∪Yn​. Notice that for any 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n,

    Yi⊆⋃j=1nYj⊆⋃α∈IUα.Y_i \subseteq \bigcup_{j=1}^n Y_j \subseteq \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} U_\alpha.Yi​⊆j=1⋃n​Yj​⊆α∈I⋃​Uα​.

Exercise 2.3.4

Let (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​), (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​), (Z,dZ)\p{Z, d_Z}(Z,dZ​) be metric spaces, and let f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y and g ⁣:Y→Z\func{g}{Y}{Z}g:Y→Z be uniformly continuous functions. Show that g∘f ⁣:X→Z\func{g \circ f}{X}{Z}g∘f:X→Z is also uniformly continuous.
